bibl.title: Letter from Rupert Blue to Henry Rose Carter, February 21, 1918

div1.p: Blue writes that he opposes War Department control of the U.S. Public Health Service.

div1.head: Letter from Rupert Blue to Henry Rose Carter, February 21, 1918
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF THE
SURGEON GENERAL
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Washington.
Feb. 21, 1918.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
United States Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of February
7th, I beg leave to advise you that the De-
partment is opposed to the transfer of the
Public Health Service to the War Department
for the period of the war. The Secretary
believes, and the Bureau concurs in the
belief, that the conservation of public
health is a civil function, and that the
sanitation of areas adjacent to military and
naval camps and cantonments should remain
under the jurisdiction of the civil authori-
ties.

The matter of the transfer received
the favorable consideration of the Medical
Section of the Advisory Commission, Council
of National Defense, but I am under the im-
pression that Professor Welch witheld his
approval of this action.
With kind regards and best wishes,
